articles.headline: Cash-Short, U.S. Weighs Asset Sales
articles.snippet: The White House figures that selling spare land, buildings and airwaves could raise up to $22 billion over the next decade.
articles.abstract: The White House figures that selling spare land, buildings and airwaves could raise up to $22 billion over the next decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Like Americans trying to raise quick cash by unloading their unwanted goods, the federal government is considering a novel way to reduce the deficit: holding the equivalent of a garage sale.

articles.headline: In European Crisis, Experts See Little Hope for a Quick Fix
articles.snippet: In the best case, a bailout of troubled banks and governments could keep the financial system from experiencing a major shock, though easing the huge debt could take years.
articles.abstract: In the best case, a bailout of troubled banks and governments could keep the financial system from experiencing a major shock, though easing the huge debt could take years.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has happened time and again in recent months as Europe’s debt crisis has played out. Stocks stage a strong comeback on expectations that a solution has been found. Then they quickly resume their decline as hopes dissipate, leaving investors puzzled and frazzled.
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: Hungary Blames the Banks
articles.snippet: The government has enacted a law permitting homeowners to pay off certain mortgages at more favorable rates, outraging Europe’s financial establishment.
articles.abstract: The government has enacted a law permitting homeowners to pay off certain mortgages at more favorable rates, outraging Europe’s financial establishment.
articles.lead_paragraph: Homeowners took risks in 2005 and 2006 that came to seem foolish, if not reckless, and wound up with mortgages they could not afford. Some blamed the banks for luring them into taking the risks. The banks offered some modifications, but said they believed it was the homeowner who should suffer for gambling and losing.

articles.headline: Outsize Severance Continues for Executives, Even After Failed Tenures
articles.snippet: Eye-popping severance packages thrive in spite of the measures put in place in the wake of the financial crisis to crack down on excessive pay.
articles.abstract: Eye-popping severance packages thrive in spite of the measures put in place in the wake of the financial crisis to crack down on excessive pay.
articles.lead_paragraph: The golden goodbye has not gone away.

articles.headline: Activists in Arab World Vie to Define Islamic State
articles.snippet: Many Islamic political activists say struggles between puritanical and liberal Islamists may now be more important than their battles against secularists.
articles.abstract: Many Islamic political activists say struggles between puritanical and liberal Islamists may now be more important than their battles against secularists.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — By force of this year’s Arab revolts and revolutions, activists marching under the banner of Islam are on the verge of a reckoning decades in the making: the prospect of achieving decisive power across the region has unleashed an unprecedented debate over the character of the emerging political orders they are helping to build.
articles.byline: By Anthony Shadid and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Banks to Make Customers Pay Fee for Using Debit Cards
articles.snippet: Banks are imposing new charges on their customers to make up for the revenue they expect to lose because of a cap on what they can charge merchants for debit-card transactions.
articles.abstract: Banks are imposing new charges on their customers to make up for the revenue they expect to lose because of a cap on what they can charge merchants for debit-card transactions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bank of America, the nation’s biggest bank, said on Thursday that it planned to start charging customers a $5 monthly fee when they used their debit cards for purchases. It was just one of several new charges expected to hit consumers as new regulations crimp banks’ profits.
articles.byline: By Tara Siegel Bernard and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Obama Charts a New Route to Re-election
articles.snippet: With his support among blue-collar white voters far weaker than among white-collar independents, President Obama is pinning his hopes on changing demographics in formerly Republican states.
articles.abstract: With his support among blue-collar white voters far weaker than among white-collar independents, President Obama is pinning his hopes on changing demographics in formerly Republican states.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With his support among blue-collar white voters far weaker than among white-collar independents, President Obama is charting an alternative course to re-election should he be unable to win Ohio and other industrial states traditionally essential to Democratic presidential victories.
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Two-Year Manhunt Led to Killing of Awlaki in Yemen
articles.snippet: Anwar al-Awlaki, a leader in Al Qaeda’s outpost in Yemen, did not leave much of a trail, frustrating the American and Yemeni intelligence officials pursuing him.
articles.abstract: Anwar al-Awlaki, a leader in Al Qaeda’s outpost in Yemen, did not leave much of a trail, frustrating the American and Yemeni intelligence officials pursuing him.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Anwar al-Awlaki did not leave much of a trail, frustrating the American and Yemeni intelligence officials pursuing him over the last two years.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, Eric Schmitt and Robert F. Worth
